Description:
Iran says the latest move by French satellite operator Eutelsat to take the English-language news network Press TV off air reveals the true face of the so-called advocates of freedom of expression.

"While Europe hosts many channels that promote violence and terrorism against Iran, the Eutelsat satellite removed Press TV channel from its list due to the sanctions of the European Union!" Iranian Foreign Ministry spokesman Nasser Kan'ani said in a post on his Twitter account on Thursday.

“The new measure against Press TV further exposes the true face of those claiming to advocate freedom of expression and free flow of information,” he added.

#Iran #PressTV #Eutelsat #EU #Sanction
Image Text: CT RESST PRESST PRESSTV.IR Press TV sanctions: Iran decries West hypocrisy on freedom of expression

Description:
Iran will sell surface-to-surface ballistic missiles to Russia for use in its war against Ukraine, in addition to its supply of kamikaze drones, Western security officials said according to a Washington Post report. 

Intelligence reports shared by officials allege that Russia will purchase the Iranian-made Fateh-110 and Zolfaghar short-range missiles. Iran is already preparing the first shipment for a deal the Post says was finalized on September 18.

Ukrainian Defense Minister Oleksii Reznikov claimed that Russia was depleting its high-precision missile arsenal. He claimed that Russia only has 124 Iskander surface-to-surface missiles. 

#news #newsalert #newsflash #teheran #newsupdates #newstoday #breakingnews #worldnews #latestnews #kyiv #putin #politics #news #history #ukraine #middleeast #report #ukrainewar #missiles #drone #iranian #iran
Image Text: IRAN TO SELL MISSILES TO RUSSIA IN ADDITION TO SUICIDE DRONES -REPORT WHT NEWS

ukrainian defense minister oleksii reznikov claimed that russia was depleting its high-precision missile arsenal. he claimed that russia only has 124 iskander surface-to-surface missiles.

Description:
SpaceX's internet service provider, Starlink, has really been raking in the subscribers - over 1 million active ones, to be exact! But hold the champagne popping, because according to a report by Ookla, Starlink's median download speeds have been on a downward spiral in every country they track. Maybe it's because of all those new users weighing down the system? In any case, SpaceX introduced a fair use policy in November to help ease the strain - basically, if you use too much internet and exceed your data limits, they'll throttle your speeds and make you pay extra to restore them. Don't worry though, because SpaceX has a plan to fix all this - they're launching their second generation of Starlink satellites before the end of the year. Fingers crossed that helps lighten the load!

#spacex #starlink

Description:
The scenes from Iran are striking -- women are removing their head scarves and waving them defiantly in public while some are burning their veils and throwing them into bonfires to the cheers of men. 

The country has been swept by popular revolt sparked by the death of a 22-year-old Mahsa Amini, who died after being arrested by the capital’s morality police, which enforces the Islamic dress code.

By now, the protests have spread to at least 50 cities. 

Political activist and journalist Mohammad Sadegh Javadihessar told @radiofarda he had never witnessed such widespread unity regarding violence against women. "I think this could be a watershed moment in social behaviors in Iran."

Several people in Tehran told RFE/RL on September 21 that they could not access the Internet using their cell phones. Instagram, one of the few social media sites not blocked in Iran, was inaccessible, while users also said they could not access the popular WhatsApp.

For more, click link in bio. 

#iranprotests #mahsaamini #iran

Description:
The head of Iran's powerful Revolutionary Guards warned protesters that Saturday would be their last day of taking to the streets, in the clearest sign that security forces may intensify their fierce crackdown on nationwide unrest. ⁠
⁠
Iran has been gripped by protests since the death of 22-year-old Kurdish woman Mahsa Amini in the custody of the morality police last month, posing one of the boldest challenges to the clerical leadership since the 1979 revolution. ⁠
⁠
"Do not come to the streets! Today is the last day of the riots," Revolutionary Guards commander Hossein Salami said in some of the toughest language used in the crisis, which Iran's leaders blame on its foreign enemies including Israel and the United States. ⁠
⁠
"This sinister plan, is a plan hatched ... in the White House and the Zionist regime," Salami said. "Don't sell your honor to America and don't slap the security forces who are defending you in the face." ⁠
⁠
Iranians have defied such warnings throughout the popular revolt in which women have played a prominent role. There were more reports of fresh bloodshed and renewed protests on Saturday. ⁠
⁠
Human rights group Hengaw reported security forces shooting students at a girls' school in the city of Saqez. In another post, it said security forces opened fire on students at Kurdistan University of Medical Science, in the Kurdistan provincial capital of Sanandaj. ⁠
⁠
👉Tap the link in our bio to learn more. ⁠
• ⁠
• ⁠
• ⁠
• ⁠
• ⁠
#iran #photography #photojournalism #voanews
Image Text: Iran Revolutionary Guard Chief Warns Protesters: 'Today Is Last Day of Riots' Reuters

Description:
@the.wellness.therapist :
To the international community, our sisters & brothers in Iran have lost access to the internet. They are risking their lives by simply refusing to wear the hijab & to peacefully protest. The regime of the Islamic Republic of Iran has shut down their connection to the outside world. They are being killed in the dark. I humbly ask for your support in sharing their stories & how they are courageously risking life & limb just to be heard

Iranians are asking for those outside of Iran to their voice. Share their stories. Don’t let their deaths be in vain. Scroll to learn ways to help them & share this post along with others
 
1. Repost footage of protests to all social media platforms

The Islamic Republic of Iran regime is blocking the internet. Iranians have to use VPN & other dangerous methods to get content out. When we reshare the videos/photos that do get out, we are helping to amplify the voices of Iranians. They want us to help get their stories out

Doing so also scares the regime because they don’t want the international community to see what is happening. Footage being widespread online also raises morale of Iranians to keep protesting

2. Use specific & creative hashtAgs to get thE word out
Use these tags when you post
#mahsaamini #jinaamini #zhinaamini #Mahsa_Amini #iran #iranprotests

The tags above are designed for those who are already aware of whats happening in Iran
To get the story out to those who aren’t aware of it, use other popular hashtags such as
#food #fall #halloween #family #love #photography #news #politics etc. get creative!

3. No war. No western intervention.
Keep your support focused on Iranian people fighting for their own liberation. Say No war on Iran. Iranians don’t want Western foreign intervention. They want to fight for their own liberation. They just want support from the international community. They want the atrocities documented

4. Organize to support iranians where you live 
Go out in the streets & make some noise. Attend support rallies in your country. DISCLAIMER: Due to sanctions against Iran, it is illegal to fundraise to send money there legally. If you see people collecting funds, be weary

Description:
You can follow these instructions to know how to connect to a proxy server for WhatsApp:

How to connect to proxy on Android phone

1. In the Chats tab, tap More options > Settings.

2. Tap Storage and Data > Proxy.
3. Tap Use Proxy.
4. Tap Set Proxy and enter the proxy address.
5. Tap Save.
6. A check mark will show if the connection is successful.
7. If you are still unable to send or receive WhatsApp messages using a proxy, that proxy may have been blocked. You can long-press the blocked proxy address to delete it, then enter a new proxy address to try again.

How to Connect to a Proxy on an Apple iPhone

1. Go to WhatsApp Settings.
2. Tap Storage and Data > Proxy.
3. Tap Use Proxy.
4. Enter the proxy address and tap Save to connect.
5. A check mark will show if the connection is successful.
6. If you are still unable to send or receive WhatsApp messages using a proxy, that proxy may have been blocked. Try again using a different proxy address.

Head to our IG story section or click the link in bio to know more 

#whatsapp #technology #internetshutdown #pragnews

Description:
It’s so much I don’t even know where to begin…
Begin to formulate into words how my life and my body has been harmed growing up in Iran placed in the category of female. 
It won’t happen in a post, or even ten…. Which part of it should I talk about even? Should I talk about the childhood they stole from me? The safety? The freedom? Or the fear I felt every day going out in the world? The countless small moments of harassment of my body that had become so normal I didn’t even think to tell anyone? Should I speak about the abusive relationship I was in and how the system kept me from escaping? Should I talk about the anxiety of morality police and body policing that even followed me to Berlin and the times I automatically reached for my headscarf after seeing a german police van pass me by? Like a reflex, practiced so many times it was almost instant. 
Should I talk about the years I didn’t have words to explain what happened to me? Or after I found the words constantly being silenced by so called activists and feminists and antiractists that always told me not now, or calling out everyone for not posting about their issues but when it came to iran (or anywhere that wasn’t the west) it was “well we can’t care about EVERYTHING..” 
Should I talk about the fact that I couldn’t escape the country that sentenced me to be a second class citizen or not being able to go back to a home that never felt like home? Should I tell you how it feels to choose between my autonomy and my safety? That deciding to speak out meant saying goodbye to the possibility to mend a part of me, the possibility to enjoy the beauty of my homeland and to speak in my mother tongue and be understood by strangers? 
Maybe I will tell you all about it some time,  but for now, I’m processing for the first time. I am able to open this chapter of my life without shame (including my shame) for the world. I am inviting you to listen to our stories, to feel with us. All of us who were not only silenced in our home country but even after and felt so voiceless for so long. I am beginning to let this part of me speak and it has a lot to say. #womanlifefreedom #mahsaamini #jinaamini #opiran #زن_زندگی_آزادی

Description:
We, a group of scientists and health care workers from around the world (including physicians, dentists, nurses, pharmacists, and other allied health groups), stand in solidarity and in one voice with the brave people of Iran fighting for freedom and democracy against the brutal fundamentalist regime.

According to the Geneva Convention, under no circumstances shall any health care worker be punished for carrying out medical activities, and persons engaged in medical activities shall not be compelled to carry out work contrary to the rules of medical ethics.

In the past few weeks, Iranian health care workers have been systematically subjected to harassment, intimidation, and threats from the Iranian government. They have been detained and tortured while in custody and forced to provide false statements under duress. They have been humiliated and abused, both physically and mentally. Our colleagues have been forced to flee their country solely due to caring for injured protesters, a task that is the very core of their profession.

We have clear goals for this movement, which are as follows: 
1. Immediate and unconditional release of physicians, dentists, pharmacists, and nurses. 2. Cessation of pursuit and arrest of the wounded protestors in forms of threats and harassment that prevent the delivery of prompt and quality care by the health care team. 4. Immediate cessation of violent attacks on health care workers while on duty. 5. Prohibit all security forces and plainclothes officers from entering hospitals or medical facilities, arresting injured protestors or the health care team who are assisting them. 6. Stop using ambulances as military vehicles carrying regime’s security personnel instead of injured patients.
We call on all human rights organizations and international communities to pressure the Islamic Republic of Iran, a signatory to the Geneva Convention treaties, to adhere to these treaties and hold it accountable otherwise.

#MahsaAmini
#Mohammad_Mehdi_Karmi #Ali_Moazemi_Goderzai
#Behrad_Ali_Kenar #Reza_shaker_zavardehi
#Javad_Zargaran
#Mohammad_amin_Akhlaghi #Syed_Mohammad_Hosseini
#Shayan_Charani
#Mehdi_Mohammadi
#Arin_Farzam_Nia

Description:
My baba, cousin, and I worked together to write an op ed to the @bostonglobe . While our original version is a bit more intense, and longer, this shortened edited version gets our point across. // 

On Sept. 13, Mahsa Amini, also known by her Kurdish first name Jina, was arrested by the morality police. She was taken into custody and later became unconscious. She was taken to a hospital in a coma the next day. She was pronounced dead on Sept. 16. The Iranian government said she died from a pre-existing medical condition. However, reports indicated she died from a skull fracture due to heavy blows to the head. Since then, thousands of Iranians have marched in the streets in opposition to the rules of compulsory hijab, the lack of accountability, and the use of force by the regime to silence dissent. Many have been killed in the protests.

While strong support has come from many corners of the world, most of the West has been largely silent. Many groups that have supported the right to wear hijab for Muslim American women, based on the right to freedom of religion, ignore the fact that the compulsory hijab policy in Iran tramples women’s rights, and in fact is used as a weapon to discriminate against and punish those who resist. The law of compulsory hijab is unjust and anti-democratic and did not exist before the current authoritarian government came to power in 1979. For progressive organizations and individuals who have spent their lives supporting and fighting for women’s rights, equality, and bodily autonomy, please raise your voices in support of Iranian women’s struggle for democracy and control of their rights and bodies. No woman should die because a few strands of her hair were not covered by a piece of cloth.
Image Text: MENU OPINION Revolution in Iran, silence America For progressive organizations who have supported women's rights, please raise your voices in support of Iranian women's struggle for democracy and control of their rights and bodies. By Manoocher Soleimani, Sheida Soleimani, and Negah Rahmati Updated October 18, 2022, 3:00 a.m. AMINI MAHSA AMINI

Description:
Oakwyn's theme of the year for 2022 is EVOLVE…

Every day, womxn locally and around the world face discrimination, bias, inequality, sexual harassment, assault, violence and violations to their human rights. Bringing up these issues and supporting those who identify as female, is as important this year as it has been every year.

Our 6th annual WOO (Women of Oakwyn) event, will be held at The Kent Vancouver on October 20th 2022.  Our goal is to support womxn in our community, empower female business leaders, and raise money for the WOO Scholarship.  The WOO scholarship was created last year to help give financial support to womxn looking to receive certification in a business program.  We believe that female empowerment is essential to the strength of a community & society.

Keep an eye out for more information on WOO 2022… #Evolve #PositiveChange #mahsaamini

Description:
Thousands of students took to the streets last night to call for an end to gender based violence and sexual harassment. 
The march, which started at Manchester University's Owen's Park campus, and culminated at the Student's Union on Oxford Road, was part of the annual Reclaim the Night demonstration.
The historical event dates back to 1977 in Leeds, when women marched as part of a response to the Yorkshire Ripper murders, when local police instructed women to stay out of public spaces after dark.

Full story via the link in our bio 🔗 

.
.
.

#manchestereveningnews #reclaimthestreets #studentunion #manchester #owenspark #mmu #uom #studentlife #protest #march #endgenderbasedviolence #endsexualharassment #makeastand #beheard #mahsaamini #curiously

Description:
Cryptocurrency exchange Binance temporarily suspended its blockchain network after hackers made off with around $570 million worth of its BNB token.

Binance said late Thursday a cross-chain bridge linking with its BNB Chain was targeted, enabling hackers to move BNB
 tokens off the network. So-called cross-chain bridges are tools that allow the transfer of tokens from one blockchain to another.

The company said it had worked with network validators — entities or individuals who confirm transactions on the blockchain — to pause creation of new blocks on BSC, suspending all transaction processing while a team of developers investigates the breach.

Binance is the world’s largest crypto exchange by trading volume.

“An exploit on a cross-chain bridge, BSC Token Hub, resulted in extra BNB. We have asked all validators to temporarily suspend BSC,” Changpeng Zhao, Binance’s CEO, said in a tweet Thursday evening.

“The issue is contained now. Your funds are safe. We apologize for the inconvenience and will provide further updates accordingly.”

BNB Chain has since resumed operations.

In total, hackers drained 2 million BNB tokens — about $570 million at current prices — from the network, Binance’s BNB Chain said in a blog post on Friday.

The hack was caused by a bug in the bridge’s smart contract that allowed hackers to forge transactions and send money back to their crypto wallet, according to crypto security firm Immunefi. Smart contracts are pieces of code on the blockchain that allow agreements to execute automatically without human intervention.

The value of BNB sank more than 3% Friday morning to $285.36 a coin, according to CoinMarketCap data.

An earlier estimate from the company placed the total amount withdrawn in a range of $100 million to $110 million. The company also said it managed to freeze $7 million of funds with the help of its security partners.

A Binance spokesperson told CNBC the company coordinated with BNB Chain validators to enact an upgrade. That meant that most of the funds remained in the exploiter’s crypto wallet, while about $100 million was “unrecovered.”

————————————————————————-
Follow @cryptoworldpage
Image Text: @cryptoworldpage $570 MILLION WORTH OF BINANCES BNB TOKEN STOLEN IN ANOTHER MAJOR CRYPTO HACK E E WP

I have a Twitter account, but I don’t use it much. I usually very rarely go on Twitter. I find people on Twitter mean, angry, and there’s so many trolls. Of course this is before Elon musk purchased it!! Now, it’s gonna be really scary. Billionaires owning all of our media is part of the oligarchy. This is very dangerous. Very dangerous especially those have been radicalized by the far right. This is a sad time.

I’m about to delete my Twitter account because I don’t need to be traumatized by racist, bigots and incels .

Description:
📷: UGC images posted on social media on October 26, 2022, show thousands making their way toward Aichi cemetery in Saqez, Mahsa Amini's hometown in the western Iranian province of Kurdistan, to mark 40 days since her death. ⁠
⁠
👉Amateur video posted to social media sites showed crowds of protesters, some in vehicles but mostly on foot, filling the road leading to Aichi cemetery in the Kurdistan province city Saqez, which was Amini’s hometown. Witnesses reported shots being fired in the area by Iranian security forces. ⁠
⁠
The demonstrators, who could be heard yelling, “Death to the dictator” among other chants, marched in defiance of heightened security measures put in place in anticipation of further protests Wednesday. ⁠
⁠
VOA’s Persian service reported protesters also gathered in Tehran, where they chanted "Down with the dictator" and "Don't be afraid, we are all together." ⁠
⁠
Amini, a Kurdish woman, was detained by the morality police in the capital, Tehran, September 13 allegedly wearing her head scarf — or hijab — "improperly." The 22-year-old died while custody three days later, with police reporting she had a heart attack. Her family says she had no history of heart trouble. ⁠
⁠
Tap the link in our bio to learn more. ⁠
• ⁠
• ⁠
• ⁠
• ⁠
• ⁠
#iran #photography #photojournalism #voanews

The Iranian regime's officials use twitter and other Western platforms to broadcast their lies and propaganda. These hypocrites constantly chant "Death to America" as they use American apps, technology, and products, while they ban Iranian citizens from using them.

Pictured here are:
1) Ali Khamenei - The Supreme Leader (Dictator)

2) Ebrahim Raisi - "President" whose primary role is to be Khamenei's mouthpiece. There are millions of highly educated Iranians but this president doesn't have any formal non-religious education beyond the sixth grade. "Presidential elections" in Iran are a charade. All candidates are handpicked by the dictator.

3) Esmail Qaani - Commander of the Quds Force, a branch of IRGC, responsible for committing numerous acts of terrorism. Also appointed by the dictator.

4) Mohammad Bagher Ghalibaf - Speaker of the circus called parliament. Responsible for executive affairs to ensure the theocratic legal system that oppresses the nation remains intact.

7) Peyman Jebelli - Director of the state-owned media that controls all domestic radio & TV services in Iran. Appointed by the dictator to use the media to spread the regime's lies and propaganda.

8) Ali Bahadori Jahromi - Spokesperson for the regime. His job is to spread misinformation, especially in regards to the suffering of the people at the hands of the regime. Many of his lies are unintentionally (or knowingly) repeated by some journalists outside of Iran.

9 & 10) And some of the numerous other previous and current regime officials (many have verified accounts)

Iranian citizens are banned from using Twitter, but their oppressors, these criminals and terrorists, are free to operate, while many videos exposing the crimes of this regime are removed by Twitter, Facebook, and Instagram.

Updated: #noushinzandvakil #shararehsaebimonfared #reyhanearmaghani are ALL FREED from prison 

When you share about people being held in prison in Iran, specifically by name, you are helping save their life. 
Fame buys safety.

On Nov 24, the UN Human Rights Council @unitednationshumanrights voted for a Fact-Finding Mission, into examining the human rights abuses In
Iran. This puts even more pressure on the
regime to portray a good image internationally.
Since the UN vote, the regime in recent days has released hundreds of detainees like Katayoun Mahmoudifar. Some of these released detainees include a prominent human rights activist, a famous 
actress and two former footballers among others. 
Posting on social media is the BEST way to help! 
Iranians are begging us to keep posting so that the regime is put under pressure. The Islamic Regime of Iran knows the world is watching, and is afraid of being held accountable.

One of the slides has a TW. While it may feel overwhelming to read; please remember that it is reality for many Iranians. Turning our eyes away from their pain, is invalidating their suffering. When we are aware, we are able to amplify better. 

Reach out to Iranians you know in your community. All of them are undergoing severe mental distress. Send them love, strength and solidarity. Ask how you can support them better. Share posts that they are sharing & stand united with them.

There is nothing as isolating than to have your yoga teacher or fellow practitioner invalidate what you, or the people in your country are going through. If you are a non-Iranian reach out to your yoga teacher and ask him/her to share. 
Stand in Solidarity. 

Simultaneously, do stand in solidarity with people from across the world facing war, protests, oppression, systemic violence, ethnic cleansing, genocide, gender/religious/race & caste based violence, climate events… 
From Palestine, Kashmir, Ukraine, China, Syria, India to Tibet…

“Nobody's free until everybody's free.”

Description:
On September 20, 2022, 16-year-old Nika Shakarami went missing after she took part in the protests against Mahsa Amini in Tehran. Her family was informed of her death ten days later.
The late teenager’s family were not allowed to see the body and were only allowed to look at her face for a few seconds for identification purposes.
Shakarami’s mother and aunt saw that her nose had been smashed and her skull was broken. The official death certificate cited “multiple blows caused by a hard object” as the cause of death.
The death of the teenager enraged citizens and led to high school girls joining the anti-government protests in large numbers on October 4.
The Iranian authorities claimed she died due to falling from a height, however, Shakarami’s mother Nasrin accused the Iranian authorities of murdering her daughter and pressuring her to say that she died by suicide after she jumped from the roof of a building.
Her family planned to bury Shakarami in Khorramabad, on October 2, which would have been her 17th birthday. However, they alleged that the security forces pressured them into not holding a funeral service.
Reportedly, the late teenager’s aunt, Atash Shakarami, defied the security forces and posted about the funeral on Twitter and invited people to join the celebration of her niece’s “last birthday”. Shortly afterwards, she and her husband were arrested.
On October 5, Iranian state television aired interviews where Atash stated that the teenager fell from the roof. The interview was reportedly filmed while they were in government custody. Shakarami’s mother also claimed that her sister was “forced to make the confession and broadcast them”.
Her family further alleged that Shakarami’s body was stolen and buried in Hayat Ol Gheyb to prevent publicity and prevent her grave from becoming a pilgrimage site for protesters.

Report: Ritika Joshi
Read more on our site

#stp #stpnews #shethepeople #nikashakarami #mahsaamini #iran #iranprotests #iranian #iranianprotesters #tehran #khorramabad

Description:
The PC version of GTA Online has been experiencing a new wave of malicious hacks and exploits due to the recent leak of the game's source code.

Players who log in without a firewall may experience modified stats, account bans, data corruption, and PC impact from cheat engines.

Fans are concerned as Rockstar's security teams are working to address the issue, but some are calling for players to avoid the game altogether or invest in a strong firewall. 

This comes on top of previous criticism of Rockstar's recent handling of their other game, Red Dead Online.

Description:
The Long Beach Unified School District announced the launch of a new anonymous reporting system for middle school students, high school students and adults. Anyone who feels there’s a threat or “concerning behavior” can use the Say Something Anonymous Reporting System to reach out.

The system provides a mobile app, website, and telephone hotline that’s monitored 24/7/365 by a dedicated national crisis center.

“The system is for any type of serious concerns about students who may be struggling or potentially violent,” according to an LBUSD release. “Tipsters can send reports on anything from school threats they’ve seen or overheard to personal crises including sexual harassment, self-harm, abuse, bullying and depression.”

The website saysomething.net allows students to submit tips directly, but links will also be available on district and school websites. The mobile app is also available for download on the Apple App Store and Google Play. Students can also submit tips through the hotline by calling 1-844-5-SAYNOW.

For the full story click the link in our bio, where you can also sign up for our newsletters or become a member to support local journalism

#longbeach #school #safety
Image Text: LBP 90 LBUSD launches anonymous reporting system for safety concerns

Description:
📷: A UGC picture posted October 27, 2022, shows Iranian women who aren’t wearing hijabs sitting across from security forces in a square in Tehran. ⁠
⁠
👉The head of Iran's powerful Revolutionary Guards warned protesters that Saturday would be their last day of taking to the streets, in the clearest sign that security forces may intensify their fierce crackdown on nationwide unrest. ⁠
⁠
Since the death of 22-year-old Kurdish woman Mahsa Amini in the custody of the morality police last month, Iran has been gripped by protests, posing one of the boldest challenges to the clerical leadership since the 1979 revolution. ⁠
⁠
"Do not come to the streets! Today is the last day of the riots," Guards commander Hossein Salami said in some of the toughest language used in the crisis, which Iran's leaders blame on its foreign enemies including Israel and the United States. ⁠
⁠
"This sinister plan, is a plan hatched ... in the White House and the Zionist regime," Salami said. "Don't sell your honor to America and don't slap the security forces who are defending you in the face." ⁠
⁠
Iranians have defied such warnings throughout the popular revolt, in which women have played a prominent role. There were more reports of fresh bloodshed and renewed protests on Saturday. ⁠
⁠
Human rights group Hengaw reported security forces shooting students at a girls school in the city of Saqez. In another post, it said security forces opened fire on students at Kurdistan University of Medical Science, in the Kurdistan provincial capital of Sanandaj. ⁠
⁠
👉Tap the link in our bio to learn more. ⁠
• ⁠
• ⁠
• ⁠
• ⁠
• ⁠
#iran #tehran #photography #photojournalism #voanews

Description:
follow @_the.wellness.therapist for up-to-date info on what’s happening in Iran (as well as a lot of other great info)

——- original caption ——-

To the international community, our sisters & brothers in Iran have lost access to the internet. They are risking their lives by refusing to wear the hijab & peacefully protesting. The Islamic Republic of Iran regime has shut down their connection to the outside world. They’re being killed in the dark. I humbly ask for your support in sharing their stories since they cannot. 

Iranians are asking for those on the outside to be their voice. Share their stories. Don’t let their deaths be in vain.

1. Repost footage of protests to all social media platforms 

The Islamic Republic of Iran regime  is blocking the internet. Iranians have to use VPN & other dangerous methods to get content out. When we reshare the videos/photos that do get out, we are helping to amplify the voices of Iranians.

Doing so also scares the regime because they don’t want the international community to see what is happening. Footage being widespread online also raises morale of Iranians to keep protesting. 

2. Use specific & creative hashtAgs to get thE word out 

Use these tags when you post: 
#mahsaamini #jinaamini #zhinaamini #Mahsa_Amini #iran #iranprotests

The tags above are designed for those who are already aware of whats happening in Iran. To get the story out to those who aren’t aware of it, use other popular hashtags such as: 

#food #fall #halloween #family #love #photography #news #politics . get creative! 

3. No war. No western intervention.
Keep your support focused on Iranian people fighting for their own liberation. Say No war on Iran. Iranians don’t want Western foreign intervention. They want to fight for their own liberation. They just want support from the international community. They want the atrocities documented. 

4. Organize to support iranians where you live  Go out in the streets & make some noise. Attend support rallies in your country.

@instagram hitting us hard with the shadow ban for posting so much about the #iranrevolution in our stories. We went from 500-2000 likes on each post to barely 50. Not really a coincidence at this point. Where’s the humanity & #freespeech ? Guess it doesn’t exist in #meta 😏 Huge disappointment a community originally created to bring people together is keeping us all from helping one another. It’s not going to slow us down! Despite what is being said on MSM, our Iranian followers assure us that there was no abolishment of the morality police. It is a PR stunt on behalf of the Iranian government because of the world’s reaction to the heinous activities & executions of its people. Show your support by turning on notifications & never missing a post or story by us ♥️ If we don’t have each other, we don’t have anything. 🌍 #themoreyouknow 
And now, a little bit of fashion. #nfmfeaturepost @nervimilano

Description:
🇮🇷 One of Iran’s most famous actresses, Taraneh Alidoosti, was arrested after posting a photo without her hijab showing solidarity with Iranian protestors  and speaking out against the execution of a protester.

Alidoosti starred in the 2016 Oscar-winning film “The Salesman.” Her post was made on Instagram last month that read, "Women, Life, Freedom" — her account has since been removed and she was arrested shortly after the post was made.

“Your silence means supporting tyranny and tyrants," she also said when speaking about the execution of a protester. "Every international organization who is watching this bloodshed and not taking action, is a disgrace to humanity."

"I will stand by the families of prisoners and the killed and will demand justice for them. I will fight for my home and I will pay any cost to stand for my rights.”

Iranian security forces removed her from her home and placed her under arrest after the post was made.

She was arrested for posting false information with a “lack of evidence for her claims” and supporting anti-Iranian movements.

"Some celebrities make claims without evidence and publish provocations and have been thus arrested," the state news agency added.

@thenormalnews 

#taranehalidoosti #iranrevolution #mahsaamini #mahsa_amini #iranrevolution2022 #iranprotests2022 #iran🇮🇷

Description:
The sentencing of prominent teachers and labor rights advocates to prison in Iran amid a violent crackdown on protests that has seen hundreds killed, including children, more than 12,000 arrested, and hundreds facing sham charges is a prelude to more severe repression if the international community does not act now, said the Center for Human Rights in Iran (CHRI).

“All across Iran, protesters have been risking their lives to call for an end to the Islamic Republic’s violent repression,” said Ghaemi.

“The state’s attempts to crush peaceful protest through killings, arrests, and imprisonment is a prelude to more severe state violence against Iran’s citizenry, which can only be halted through strong, collective, international action,” he said.

* CHRI calls on the Islamic Republic to release a public accounting of all political prisoners and detainees and their whereabouts, as well as a public listing of all those who have been killed since September 16, 2022, when anti-state protests erupted in the country.

* CHRI also urges the international community, including government leaders, the UN, and bar associations across the world, to call on the government in Iran to release all detained protesters and political prisoners and halt its crackdown on peaceful dissent.

* The U.S. and its partners should also pursue the establishment of an urgent special session at the U.N. Human Rights Council so that governments can collectively address the violence against protesters and establish an investigative, reporting, and accountability mechanism for the Islamic Republic’s many serious crimes.

Read more of our recommendations for the international community, and about this story, on our website (link in bio). 

#Iran #IranProtests #IranProtests2022 #HumanRights #UN #FreeSpeech #Revolution #OpIran #MahsaAmini #IranRevolution #WomensRights #IranRevolution #Iranian #Tehran #Mahsa_Amini #b2210

Description:
The death of Mahsa Amini, a 22-year-old Iranian woman triggered widespread protests. Protestors are reportedly chopping their hair, burning down the hijab, and dressing up as men to oppose the moral policing of police and the system. 
On social media, videos of Iranian women cutting their hair and burning their hijabs are spreading amid growing outrage. Iranian protesters also took to the streets with antigovernmental slogans at a gathering in Saqez, Amini’s hometown. The crowd came from nearing cities in Kurdistan province. The protestors raised slogans like Death to the dictator – a reference to Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, while some women threw their headscarves. 
Videos shared on social media also showed protesters assembling near the University of Tehran. The crowd raised slogans like Woman, Life, Freedom. Thousands of Iranian women staged protest rallies in the capital on weekend. Police fired tear gas shells to resist the protest. 
The death of Amini in the custody of morality police has forced women to take to the streets in protest and put a spotlight on their repression. 
Amini died on 16 September, Friday after being detained by the police unit liable for enforcing the Islamic republic’s strict dress code for women. Reports say that she fell into a coma post-arrest in Tehran. Media reports stated a heart attack as a reason after being detained by the morality police.
Reportedly, Amini was thrashed by police when they detained her in the police van. However, police have denied the allegations, saying Amini had “suddenly suffered a heart problem”. Amini’s family claimed their daughter was perfectly healthy.
Amini’s death erupted the protest, but seeds of distress were already sown due to growing reports of repressive acts against women. Women over the age of seven have to strictly cover their hair and wear long, loose-fitting clothes as per Iran’s sharia law. 
President Ebrahim Raisi passed an order on July 5, to enforce the hijab law, which carved a new list of restrictions on how women can dress. 

Image Credit: Masih Alinejad 

Report: Snehal Mutha
Read more on our site

#stp #stpnews #iran #mahsaamini #hijab #protest #tehran #iranianwomen

Description:
Thousands defy heightened Iran security to mourn Mahsa Amini

This UGC image posted on Twitter reportedly on Wednesday shows an unveiled woman standing on top of a vehicle as thousands make their way towards Aichi cemetery in Saqez, Mahsa Amini's home town in the western Iranian province of Kurdistan, to mark 40 days since her death, defying heightened security measures as part of a bloody crackdown on women-led protests. A wave of unrest has rocked Iran since 22-year-old Amini died on Sept. 16 following her arrest by the morality police in Tehran for allegedly breaching the country's strict rules on hijab headscarves and modest clothing. 

UGC, AFP

#MahsaAmini

Description:
CRACKDOWN CONTINUES

❗️WHAT: Iranian authorities have arrested one of the country’s most famous and Oscar-winning actor, Taraneh Alidoosti. 

👉🏼 WHY: On Dec 8, Iran executed a 23-year-old named Mohsen Shekari, after convicting and sentencing him to death for blocking a street and wounding a paramilitary officer during the early phase of the protests in mid-September.

🎙️ Alidoosti had criticised international organisations for not speaking out against the execution, on Instagram. Watching this bloodshed and not taking action, is a disgrace to humanity,” she wrote.

🇮🇷 Iran arrested her for spreading falsehoods/making claims without any supporting documents. 

❗️ Alidoosti’s Instagram account, which had eight million followers, has been suspended. 

🗓️ Last month, she had posted a her picture without the hijab and held a piece of paper reading “women, life, freedom”, the rallying cry of the current anti-regime protests sweeping the country. 

📌 A TREND: In November, the authorities detained Hengameh Ghaziani and Katayoun Riahi, two other renowned Iranian actors, for expressing solidarity with the protests on social media.

📌 Authorities also arrested Iranian football player Voria Ghafouri last month for “insulting the national soccer team and propagandising against the government”. 

❗️DID YOU KNOW: Courts in and around Tehran have recently sentenced 400 detained protestors to prison sentences of up to 10 years. 

#newsworthywithab #iranprotests #iranprotests2022 #iranprotest #mahsaamini #mahsaaminiمهسا_امینی

Description:
United States coach Gregg Berhalter apologized on Monday for the furore triggered by a social media post depicting Iran's flag without the word Allah as the two geopolitical foes prepared for their crunch World Cup showdown.

#US Soccer sparked uproar over the weekend after posting an Iranian flag without its Islamic Republic emblem on the federation's social media feeds in what it claimed was a gesture of solidarity with Iranian women protesters.

Berhalter told a press conference on Monday that the US players and coaching staff had been oblivious about the posts as he sought to calm tensions surrounding Tuesday's Group B game, where a place in the last 16 is at stake.

"Sometimes things are out of our control," Berhalter said. "We're not focused on those outside things and all we can do is apologize on behalf of the players and the staff, but it's not something that we were a part of.

"We had no idea what US Soccer put out. The staff, the players, we had no idea. For us our focus is on this match and I don't want to sound aloof, or we're not caring by saying that.

"Of course our thoughts are with the Iranian people, the whole country, and everyone. But our thoughts are only on this match."

Earlier, Iran state media called for the United States to be kicked out of the World Cup after the USA men's national soccer team (USMNT) deleted the emblem of the Islamic Republic in a post displaying upcoming matches in Group B for the World Cup.

The USMNT defended the move by telling CNN that it was to show “support for the women in #Iran fighting for basic human rights” but was never meant to last over 24 hours.

The change “was a one-time graphic,” the soccer federation told CNN. “We have the main flag on our website and other places.”

However, Iran state media said on Twitter that “by posting a distorted image of the flag of the Islamic Republic of #Iran on its official account, the #US football team breached the @FIFAcom charter, for which a 10-game suspension is the appropriate penalty.”

It added, “Team #USA should be kicked out of the #WorldCup2022.”

FIFA, for its part, issued no response.
Image Text: ‎one or more people, ‎'‎رفيا ocaCola ENGLAND IRAN USA @万流 WANDA 万达 FIFA Men's WALES eyes Tuesday. GROUP B STANDINGS IFAN US COACH APOLOGIZES FOR FLAG UPROAR AHEAD OF IRAN MATCH RoyaNewsEnglish en.royanews.tv‎'‎‎

Description:
Hundreds of protesters marched Wednesday to the gravesite of Mahsa Amini in northwestern Iran to mark 40 days since her death while in custody of the nation’s morality police. ⁠
⁠
Amateur video posted to social media sites showed crowds of protesters, some in vehicles but mostly on foot, filling the road leading to Aichi cemetery in the Kurdistan province city Saqez, which was Amini’s hometown. Witnesses reported shots being fired in the area by Iranian security forces. ⁠
⁠
The demonstrators, who could be heard yelling, “Death to the dictator” among other chants, marched in defiance of heightened security measures put in place in anticipation of further protests Wednesday. ⁠
• ⁠
• ⁠
• ⁠
• ⁠
• ⁠
📷: Reuters ⁠
⁠
👉 Click link in bio to read more. ⁠
⁠
#Iran #Tehran #protests #VOA #VoiceofAmerica #Photojournalism #Photography

Description:
The Iranian team at the World Cup halfheartedly sang its country’s national anthem Friday, before beating the team from Wales in Iran’s second day of competition in Qatar's Ahmad bin Ali Stadium. ⁠
⁠
On Friday, boos and jeers met Iran’s anthem as the players appeared to merely mouth the lyrics. ⁠
⁠
Monday’s failure of the Iranian athletes to sing the anthem was widely viewed as a demonstration of support for the protests that erupted in Iran after Mahsa Amin, a 22-year-old woman, died in police custody after being detained for not wearing her headscarf properly. ⁠
⁠
At least four Iranian current and veteran soccer players — Veria Ghafouri, Hossein Mahini, Parviz Broumand, and Hamidreza Ali Asgari — have been taken into custody on charges of participating in or supporting the popular protests. ⁠
⁠
Some of those supporting Iran at Friday’s game against Wales were reportedly nationals from countries such as Pakistan and Bangladesh. Some social media users also reported the presence of many non-Iranian spectators, mainly foreign workers living in Qatar, holding the flags of the Islamic Republic. ⁠
⁠
People wearing clothes with slogans such as "Freedom Life Woman" or shirts with the name "Mahsa Amini" were also widely prevented from entering. ⁠
⁠
👉Tap the link in our bio to learn more. ⁠
• ⁠
• ⁠
• ⁠
•⁠
• ⁠
#iran #qatar2022 #qatar #photography #photojournalism #voanews

Description: Guillaume Adam, a Dominican bishop, described the Ethiopians as gens maxima atque potens, a very great and powerful people, divided into five kingdoms that were so strong that one of them would be sufficient to vanquish Egypt. Niccolò da Poggibonsi reported that the sultan of Egypt feared the ruler of Ethiopia, for the latter was “the greatest Sovereign in the world.” Some accounts stressed that Ethiopia controlled access to the Indian Ocean through her strategic position on the Red Sea. More often the Ethiopian king’s presumed control over the headwaters of the Nile was emphasized. Some thought Ethiopia could subject Egypt to drought by withholding the Nile waters, while others fancied that the Ethiopian ruler could speed them up and inflict a flood on the Egyptians at will. The belief that the Ethiopian kingdom was particularly potent by virtue of its control over the Nile had a long career, persisting in some quarters well into the twentieth century. GREATER ETHIOPIA The Evolution of a Multiethnic Society by Donald N. Description:
By cutting their hair, women across the world have been showing solidarity with Iranian women and their fight for freedom and against forced hijab.

In his first mural called “The Cut” ( see my previous post ), @alexsandropalombo showed Marge Simpson cutting her iconic hair in front of the Consulate General of the Islamic Republic of Iran in Milan. The consulate however had the artwork removed in less than a day. One day later, we have
“The Cut 2" ! Marge Simpson returned in front of the Consulate again and this time she was angry 😡. Just imagine her anger in the next mural! (📸 courtesy of the artist)🙏🏻🙏🏻

I’m going to dedicate this account for the time being, to cover the murals that have been created around the world to honor Mahsa Amini and the fight of Iranian women for Justice and freedom.

Please support them by raising awareness about what Iranian women are fighting for🙏🏻.

If you have a 📷 of streetart dedicated to the fight of women for equality and freedom in general (and Iranian women in particular) either tag me or use #thegraffitihub in your streetart 📷 with a chance to be featured.

 ❗️❗️❗️

Please note that by adding #thegraffitihub in your hashtags, I assume that you are ok with me to feature your media on my page. However, if you are not Ok with your content to be featured here, please message me and I will take down the content ASAP. The purpose here is to feature the great work of other artists and streetart photographers and not to violate anyone’s copyright!

❗️❗️❗️

#uniteagainstoppression #opiran #cuttinghair #protest #iranianprotests 
#mahsaamini #mahsa_amini #opiran #مهسا_امینی #مهساامینی #womanlifefreedom 
#نه_به_حجاب_اجباری 
#woman_life_freedom #زن_زندگی_آزادی
#MargeSimpson #aleXsandroPalombo #streetartmilano #streetartmilan #milanostreetart #milanstreetart #streetartitalia #streetartitaly #graffitiitalia #graffitiitaly #italystreetart

Description:
Some 500 million whatsapp accounts were hacked around the world, with data suggesting that nearly 19 million Moroccan accounts are included. 

The hackers announced on the dark web that the hacked accounts come from 84 different countries, and assured that the database is recent and the numbers are still active. 

According to Cyber News, the hacked phone numbers, with their owner's names, are currently on sale on a dark web forum, potentially exposing users to phishing attacks and spam advertisement. 

It is currently impossible to figure out who was targeted by the attack, but the same source notes that the hack was allegedly possible through “scraping”, by collecting publicly accessible data on the internet, thanks to automated software such as when users fill out online forms. 

Out of 84 countries, Morocco is reportedly the 7th most affected country, while the country with the most hacked accounts is Egypt, with nearly 45 million users, followed by Italy with more than 35 million, and the United States in third place with a total of 32 million numbers. 

#Morocco #Whatsapp #Hack 
#HespressEng
Image Text: HESPRESS ENGLISH INTERNATIONAL WHATSAPP HACK: NEARLY 19 MILLION MOROCCAN ACCOUNTS IN JEOPARDY @HespressEng

Description:
As an animal welfare organization, we don’t typically comment on international events unless they directly relate to animals and pets. However, RedRover believes deeply in the power of empathy as a guiding force for change and understands that animal suffering and human suffering are inextricably linked – and we stand with any people fighting for basic human rights and justice, in particular the rights and freedoms of women. In this vein, we want to acknowledge and support our Iranian-American staff member and all Iranians who are grieving the recent murder of Mahsa Zhina Amini, a young Kurdish Iranian woman who was taken into custody and beaten by the Iranian morality police for allegedly improperly wearing a hijab to cover her hair – a mandatory dress code for women in Iran regardless of their religious beliefs. There have been over a week of nationwide protests as the Iranian people unite to fight back against 43 years of oppression by an authoritarian regime that has stripped women of their rights and brutalized its own people with impunity.

This is not a political or religious issue, but a feminist and human rights imperative as this regime attacks its own. The government has disrupted internet access to suppress the voice of the people and prevent videos and updates from being shared with the world. In sharing this our hope is to help amplify the voices of the brave Iranians risking their lives to liberate themselves, and we invite you to share or raise awareness as well. 

**We welcome comments that contribute to a positive and constructive discussion. Hate speech, bullying, or other behaviors that are not in the spirit of a diverse and inclusive community will be deleted. Thank you.**

#MahsaAmini #IranProtests #JinaAmini #ZhinaAmini #Iran

Description:
According to a media report, Twitter, the social media company that Elon Musk recently acquired in a $44 billion deal and where he is now serving as CEO, has received an order from Elon Musk's aerospace company SpaceX for one of the larger advertising packages available from Twitter.

According to internal documents from the social media company, the campaign will advertise the Starlink satellite internet service, which is owned and operated by SpaceX, on Twitter in Spain and Australia. A Twitter "takeover" refers to the advertising campaign SpaceX is purchasing to advertise Starlink. According to two current and two former Twitter employees who asked to remain anonymous because they were not authorised to speak on behalf of the company when a company purchases one of these packages, they typically spend upwards of $250,000 to place their brand at the top of the main Twitter timeline for a full day.

On the day or days of the anticipated takeover campaign in Australia and Spain, users should see Starlink brand messaging the first three times they open the Twitter app. The recently acquired campaign was planned to run in the upcoming days, first in Australia and then in Spain. According to current and past employees, SpaceX has not traditionally acquired significant advertising packages from Twitter.

Starlink uses a constellation of satellites to deliver internet to paying customers, who must also purchase terminals from SpaceX in order to use it. Starlink was created by SpaceX with the intention of bringing high-speed internet access to people in areas that are underserved or completely unserviced by cable or fibre-optic infrastructure.

#SpaceX #ElonMusk #Twitter #News #TimesNow #TimesNowNews #InstaWithTimesNow
Image Text: TIMES NOW Elon's Space-x just purchased an advertising package on Twitter for Starlink

Description:
Iran has arrested two prominent actors who expressed solidarity with the protest movement and removed their headscarves in public in an apparent act of defiance against the regime, state media reported Sunday. Hengameh Ghaziani and Katayoun Riahi were both detained after being summoned by prosecutors in a probe into their “provocative" social media posts and media activity, the state-run IRNA news agency said.
.
Iran’s clerical leadership has been shaken by more than two months of women-led demonstrations sparked by the death in custody of Mahsa Amini. Ghaziani, a vocal critic of the crackdown on protesters, was arrested for inciting and supporting the “riots" and for communicating with opposition media.
.
The 52-year-old film star published a video on Instagram of herself removing the obligatory hijab. “Maybe this will be my last post," she wrote late Saturday. “From this moment on, whatever happens to me, know that as always, I am with the Iranian people until my last breath." In a post last week, she accused the “child-killer" Iranian government of “murdering" more than 50 children.
.
.
.
.
.
.
#iran #hijab #antihijab #iranprotests #iranrevolution #mahsaamini #protest #actor #socialmedia #hengamehghaziani #katayounriahi
Image Text: NEWS 18 Iranian Actor Removes Hijab on Social Media, Arrested A Day Later

Description:
WOMEN, LIFE, FREEDOM

📌 WHAT: Oslo-based NGO Iran Human Rights estimates that since September 17, at least 201 persons, including women and children, have been killed by Iran’s security forces and pro-government vigilante volunteers, during protests over the custodial death of 22-year-old Mahsa Amini.

🩸 Iranian security forces in Zahedan city have killed at least 90 people amid demonstrations against a police officer accused of rape in a separate case. The government has called the protesters “separatists”. 

🥀 Iran's Children's Rights Protection Society says at least 28 children have been killed. 

👉🏼 At least 1,200 people have been arrested, including at least 20 journalists, per Iran Human Rights. 

❗️Iran’s Revolutionary Guards deputy commander Ali Fadavi told Iranian media on October 5 that the "average age of the detainees from many of the recent protests was 15". 

❗️❗️ In an interview with an independent  Iranian newspaper, Iran’s Education Minister Yousef Nouri confirmed that some school students have been detained and referred to “psychological institutions” to be “reformed”. 

✊🏾 The women-led protests continue, 26 days on. They have now spread across Iran, with many activists calling the protests a national uprising. The rallying cry: Women, Life, Freedom. 

📷 The image in the post graphic has been sourced from Twitter, where people are crowdsourcing protest artwork, often anonymously from Iran. The image depicts the bleeding ear that can be seen in Mahsa Amini’s final photo from a hospital, right before she died, lending credence to eye witness claims and media reports that she was beaten by the morality policy after being detained for wearing her hijab ‘improperly’. 

#mahsaamini #mahsa_amini #mahsaaminiمهسا_امینی #mahsa #womenlifefreedom #iranprotests2022 #newsworthywithab #mahsa_amini_iran
Image Text: [NEWSWORTHY] 201 killed in Iran protests #MahsaAmini

Description:
A year after poet Baktash Abtin died in Islamic Republic state custody due to denial of medical treatment, friends gathered at his grave in Tehran under state surveillance this past weekend to honor his life.

Abtin had been sentenced to prison for his writings peacefully criticizing state policies, and had initially refused to report to prison, citing the COVID-19 pandemic, which was raging in unvaccinated Iran in 2020. Yet he was forced to go to jail and died from denial of treatment for COVID-19 months later. No official has been held accountable for the political prisoner's preventable death.

#Iran #IranProtests #IranProtests2022 #HumanRights #UN #FreeSpeech #Revolution #OpIran #Khamenei #MahsaAmini #IranRevolution #WomensRights #Iranian #Tehran #Mahsa_Amini #WomenLifeFreedom #IranRevolution2023 #StopExecutionsinIran #stopexecutioninIran
#زن_زندگی_آزادی
#زندان_اوین
#مهسا_امینی
#بکتاش_آبتین

Description:
Mehrshad Shahidi lost his life in police custody, reportedly beaten to death with batons at the IRGC Intelligence’s detention centre, according to the local media.

Shahidi, a celebrity chef, also known as Iran’s Jamie Oliver, had 25,000 followers on Instagram and posted videos of himself cooking. He died a day before his 20th birthday, as per the reports. 

#iran #iranprotests #mehrshadshahidi
Image Text: ZEENEWS ZEEN Celebrity chef Mehrshad Shahidi beaten to death amid anti-Hijab protests in Iran

Description:
Thinking of #iran and #mahsaamini and all the amazing desire for change I experienced in Teheran at the hight of the Green Movement in 2009.
Here from “Walk on my Eyes” the project I did with @serge.michel2. 
Maryam, 33 (on the left), a single mother and painter, teaches art and art history at a high school in Tehran. All her students are girls aged fourteen to eighteen. ‘Girls today are cleverer than in my generation,’ she says. ‘They know what they want and they demand their rights.’ She lets her students remove their headscarves in class and pushes the boundaries of the Islamic dress code for her live classes. ‘In most classes, models have to wear a headscarf and manteau (a sort of house coat). I let them pose in a t-shirt and trousers. I got in a bit of trouble for it.’ Pictured here with her mother, Maryam is part of a close family. ‘I have six brothers and sisters. When my father died my brothers took over his hardware store. We spend all our free time together at my mother’s house. It’s good but it can get claustrophobic.’

Description:
Posted @withrepost • @babaktafreshi A starry night in the Alborz Mountains near Tehran. For generations this volcano has been the symbol of endurance for Iranians, a unifying icon in their darkest times. The highest peak in the Middle East, Mt Damavand, is too massive for the Islamic Republic to take away from Iranians, as is their hope for freedom. What is currently happening in Iran, with brutal shooting at protestors, is crime against humanity. The world’s media and leaders remained mostly silent, with no international reporter allowed in Iran. The human rights organization @amnesty has started a petition for a UN investigation. 
For 4 decades Iranians have lost their today and tomorrow, peace and happiness. Art, culture, justice, honesty, and dignity have been constantly suppressed under the name of Islamic rules. 
In the previous two posts I explained why the largest uprising of Iranians against the Islamic Republic is started in mid-September with women rights movement. Brave young women lead this unstoppable tsunami of change. The protests are now also in major universities and high schools. 
Slide 3: enforced hijab and women control is the red line of the Islamic Republic. In an old bazaar of Tehran, women walk without hijab in a nation-wide form of protest. #4: the daughter of #minomajidi who was killed while protesting hold her cut hairs at the grave of her mother. #5: school students removed their hijab and express their disgust to ayatollahs. #6: Security forces shooting protestors in Tehran. #7: Forces attacked protesting students at Sharif University; Iran’s top university. #8: this movement started in 1979 right after the Islamic Revolution. About 100,000 women came to the streets of Tehran to protest the force use of hijab (photo by Hengameh Golestan). #iranprotests #mahsaamini #damavand

Description:
Elon Musk said Friday his rocket company SpaceX cannot indefinitely fund its Starlink internet service in Ukraine, which has helped the country's civilians and military stay online during the war with Russia. ⁠
⁠
Musk's comment on Twitter came after a media report that SpaceX had asked the Pentagon to pay for the donations of Starlink. The billionaire has been in online fights with Ukrainian officials over a peace plan he put forward that Ukraine says is too generous to Russia. ⁠
⁠
The billionaire who runs Tesla said that Starlink officials said they spend nearly $20 million a month for maintaining satellite services in Ukraine. Musk recently said that SpaceX had spent about $80 million to enable and support Starlink there. ⁠
⁠
"SpaceX is not asking to recoup past expenses, but also cannot fund the existing system indefinitely *and* send several thousand more terminals that have data usage up to 100X greater than typical households. This is unreasonable," Musk wrote Friday on Twitter. ⁠
⁠
"We’ve also had to defend against cyberattacks & jamming, which are getting harder," Musk wrote. ⁠
⁠
CNN reported on Thursday that SpaceX sent a letter to the Pentagon last month saying it could not continue to fund the Starlink service in Ukraine, and it may have to stop funding it unless the U.S. military gives the company tens of millions of dollars a month. ⁠
⁠
👉Tap the link in our bio to learn more. ⁠
- ⁠
#elonmusk #ukraine #russia #voanews
Image Text: Musk Says SpaceX Cannot Fund Ukraine's Starlink Internet Indefinitely REUTERS

Description:
WOMEN, LIFE, FREEDOM

📌 WHAT: Oslo-based NGO Iran Human Rights estimates that at least 133 persons, including women and children, have been killed in the last two weeks during protests over the custodial death of 22-year-old Mahsa Amini. 

🩸 Iranian security forces in Zahedan city, Sistan and Baluchistan province shot at protestors, killing more than 40 people on September 30.

🇮🇷 Iranian state television has confirmed 41 deaths, including security forces. 

👉🏼 Over 1,200 people have been arrested, including at least 20 journalists, per Iran Human Rights.

✊🏾 The protests continue, 16 days on. They have now spread to over 150 cities. The rallying cry: Women, Life, Freedom. 

📷 The image in the post graphic has been sourced from Twitter, where people are crowdsourcing protest artwork, often anonymously from Iran. The image depicts the bleeding ear that can be seen in Mahsa Amini’s final photo from a hospital, right before she died, lending credence to eye witness claims and media reports that she was beaten by the morality policy after being detained for wearing her hijab ‘improperly’. 

#mahsaamini #mahsa_amini #mahsa_amini #iranprotests2022 #newsworthywithab
Image Text: [NEWSWORTHY] 133 killed in Iran protests #MahsaAmini

Description:
Its the fall season in northern hemisphere  and  I  see my talented  friends  are  busy creating beautiful  orange and yellow colour  images from pies, tarts to breads and cakes. So creative,  eye-catching and inspirational.  While ,  I scroll down these  fabulous images, I  see footage from my homeland Iran.  In one video, I watch a woman face is covered with blood and in other a mother mourns on his son grave. These scenes are  heartbreaking,  overwhelming and painful. I cry, yell and feel outrageous.
It is nearly a month  since #mahsaamini  a 22 years old girl was brutaly killed by the  Islamic regime of Iran. This  was the moment of  explosion as a result of  43 years  oppression,  gender apartheid, human right violence,  corupted economy, poverty,  and dictatorship.  Since then  Iranian  from largest to smallest cities including women,  men,  universities and even  high school students united together and put  thier lives in extreme danger  to fight for their freedom.  The Islamic regime is  murdering children and youths all over the Iran and  another genocide is happening right now. The regime  has arrested many students, journalists,  actors, and lawyers. They wont let to international journalists and authorities to freely enter Iran  and report the  protests. ( everyday, I am posting several stories about the current situation inside Iran.) Furthermore,  the internet has been cut off by the regime and we are the only voice they have.  If you care about human right  and your heart aches by watching, hearing or reading the news about Iran, please share the news about Iran and be the voice of people who are fighting so hard to get their freedom back.

گیرم که در باورتان به خاک نشسته ام

و ساقه های جوانم از ضربه های تبرهایتان زخم دار است

با ریشه چه می کنید؟

گیرم که بر سر این باغ بنشسته در کمین پرنده اید

پرواز را علامت ممنوع می زنید

با جوجه های نشسته در آشیان چه می کنید؟

گیرم که می کشید

گیرم که می برید

گیرم که می زنید

با رویش ناگزیر جوانه ها چه می کنید؟ 

#mahsaamini
#nikashakarami 
#hadisnajafi
#Iranianrevolution

description_lower:
its the fall season in northern hemisphere  and  i  see my talented  friends  are  busy creating beautiful  orange and yellow colour  images from pies, tarts to breads and cakes. so creative,  eye-catching and inspirational.  while ,  i scroll down these  fabulous images, i  see footage from my homeland iran.  in one video, i watch a woman face is covered with blood and in other a mother mourns on his son grave. these scenes are  heartbreaking,  overwhelming and painful. i cry, yell and feel outrageous.
it is nearly a month  since #mahsaamini  a 22 years old girl was brutaly killed by the  islamic regime of iran. this  was the moment of  explosion as a result of  43 years  oppression,  gender apartheid, human right violence,  corupted economy, poverty,  and dictatorship.  since then  iranian  from largest to smallest cities including women,  men,  universities and even  high school students united together and put  thier lives in extreme danger  to fight for their freedom.  the islamic regime is  murdering children and youths all over the iran and  another genocide is happening right now. the regime  has arrested many students, journalists,  actors, and lawyers. they wont let to international journalists and authorities to freely enter iran  and report the  protests. ( everyday, i am posting several stories about the current situation inside iran.) furthermore,  the internet has been cut off by the regime and we are the only voice they have.  if you care about human right  and your heart aches by watching, hearing or reading the news about iran, please share the news about iran and be the voice of people who are fighting so hard to get their freedom back.

گیرم که در باورتان به خاک نشسته ام

و ساقه های جوانم از ضربه های تبرهایتان زخم دار است

با ریشه چه می کنید؟

گیرم که بر سر این باغ بنشسته در کمین پرنده اید

پرواز را علامت ممنوع می زنید

با جوجه های نشسته در آشیان چه می کنید؟

گیرم که می کشید

گیرم که می برید

گیرم که می زنید

با رویش ناگزیر جوانه ها چه می کنید؟

Description:
Protesters rallied across Iran and strikes were reported throughout the country's Kurdish region Saturday as demonstrations against the death of a woman in police custody entered their third week. ⁠
⁠
The protests, sparked by the death of Mahsa Amini, a 22-year-old from Iranian Kurdistan, have spiraled into the biggest show of opposition to Iran's clerical authorities since 2019, with dozens killed in unrest across the country. ⁠
⁠
People demonstrated in London and Paris and elsewhere on Saturday in solidarity with Iranian protesters, some holding pictures of Amini, who died three days after being arrested by the Islamic Republic's morality police for "unsuitable attire." ⁠
⁠
In Iran, social media posts showed rallies in large cities including Tehran, Isfahan, Rasht and Shiraz. ⁠
⁠
In Tehran's traditional business district of Bazaar, anti-government protesters chanted "We will be killed one by one if we don't unite," while elsewhere they blocked a main road with a fence torn from the central reservation, videos shared by the widely followed Tavsir1500 Twitter account showed. ⁠
⁠
Students also demonstrated at numerous universities. At Tehran University, dozens were detained, Tavsir1500 said. The semi-official Fars news agency said some protesters were arrested in a square near the university. ⁠
⁠
👉Tap the link in our bio to learn more. ⁠
- ⁠
#iran #voanews

Description:
#NetSnippet | An Iranian man nicknamed the “dirtiest man in the world” for not taking a shower for decades has passed away. 

Amou Haji – not his real name, but an endearing nickname given to elderly people, died on Sunday in the village of Dejgah, the New York Post reported, citing state media.

He was buried in Farashband City in Fars on Tuesday.

As per IRNA (Islamic Republic News Agency), Haji had avoided showering over fears of “getting sick. However, for the first time a few months ago, “villagers had taken him to a bathroom to wash.”

According to New York Post Haji lived in isolation for most of his life in an open brick hut, which villagers made after he started sleeping in a hole in the ground.

Locals attributed Haji’s eccentricity to “emotional setbacks” in his youth. In 2014, the Tehran Times reported that Haji also avoided fresh food, opting instead for rotted porcupine, and smoked a pipe of animal excrement.

Reportedly, a short documentary film titled “The Strange Life of Amou Haji” was made about his life in 2013.

#dirtiestman #passedaway #Iran #NortheastToday
Image Text: NET Snippet 'World's dirtiest man' dies in Iran at 94, months after first bath in 70 years NET Northeast Today @NortheastToday

Description:
Iran has released prominent actress Taraneh Alidoosti on bail almost three weeks after she was jailed for expressing solidarity with protesters.

Prior to the arrest, Alidoosti criticised the Iranian government's executions of protesters in the Mahsa Amini movement and was pictured holding a sign saying "woman, life, freedom" on Instagram. Her Instagram account has been suspended since her arrest.

The actress is best known for her role in the Oscar-winning film The Salesman. An online campaign urging the release of Alidoosti was supported by @markruffalo, Kristen Stewart, @penelopecruzoficial, Jason Momoa and many others.

#10NewsFirst #TaranehAlidoosti #Iran #MahsaAmini #WomanLifeFreedom

Description:
We stand in solidarity with the women and girls of Iran. #WomenLifeFreedom #MahsaAmini
--
UN Women Australia, like so many other organisations has been frustrated by the limited access to information from Iran, other than news reports and social media content. The recent black out of the internet, is a testament to the courage the women and girls in Iran, staring down formidable and powerful oppressors.

As the women and girls of Iran fight to get their message out, we add our voice to theirs, and keep the spotlight on focusing international attention on the plight of the women of Iran, and their ongoing fight for justice. 

Women’s rights are human rights – let the women of Iran know we stand with them. Share their stories and amplify their voices.
--
English Translation: Women, Life, Freedom.
Image Text: ‎'‎زن زندگی آزادی‎'‎

Description:
Women in Iran are burning their hijabs in protest after a young woman died while in the custody of the country’s morality police, who are charged with enforcing the country’s dress codes. 

Mahsa Amini had been detained by authorities Thursday while visiting relatives in Tehran. She had been arrested for wearing “unsuitable attire,” Reuters reports. According to members of her family and other eyewitness accounts, Amini was beaten by authorities following her arrest. 

She died while in hospital on Friday, after three days in a coma. 

State authorities have denied that Amini was beaten, and instead allege that she died of a heart attack. 

Iranians across the country have been protesting since her death, many of them women, calling for reform of Iran’s theocratic laws, including strict dress codes which require women to remain largely covered while in public. The protests have been described as the largest since 2019, which occurred amid soaring gas prices. 

“I’ve covered #Iran for 15 years and lived there for 25 yrs. I believe what we are witnessing now is nothing like before,” wrote BBC journalist Rana Rahimpour in a message posted on Twitter.

Description:
More than $600 million in crypto left bankrupt crypto company FTX’s wallets late Friday, with little clear explanation as to why.
Soon afterwards, FTX stated in its official Telegram channel that it had been hacked, instructing users not to install any new upgrades and to delete all FTX apps.

DELETE FTX from your devices now.

Description:
HAS THE MORALITY POLICE BEEN DISBANDED? WE DON'T KNOW

🎤 What we know: The morality police “has nothing to do with the judiciary and has been abolished by the same authorities who installed it.” This quote of the Attorney General Mohammad Javad Montazeri on Dec 3 at a meeting with officials to discuss the unrest, according to the Iranian Students' News Agency (ISNA) was widely reported and interpreted by international and Indian news platforms, including us (post now removed), as Iran’s morality police being disbanded.

📌Since then: Iranians have taken to social media to dismiss this news as disinformation, calling it a throwaway remark that amounts to nothing on the ground, where the the Iranian government continues to suppress protestors through arrests, and violence.

📺 Arab-language Al-Alam state television has said that foreign media were depicting Montazeri’s comments as “a retreat on the part of the Islamic Republic from its stance on hijab and religious morality as a result of the protests”, but  all that could be understood from his comments was that the morality police were not directly related to the judiciary. "No official of the Islamic Republic of Iran has said that the Guidance Patrol has been shut."

❓What we don't know: 

👉🏼 If the Attorney General's statement will actually translate into the Morality Police being withdrawn.

👉🏼 Even if the morality police is disbanded, will the government take to other methods of enforcing compliance with Sharia laws?

👉🏼 Even if the morality police is disbanded, will it lead to a change in the strict Sharia laws on how women should dress and behave in public? 

👉🏼 The official stance of the government. Iran's Ministry of Interior is yet to issue a statement. 

🇮🇷 Bottom line: Iranian protestors have dismissed this news as a superficial, half-baked attempt to divert the western media's attention. They say their demands are no longer limited to the disbanding of the morality police, they want a complete regime change. 

#mahsaamini #mahsa #mahsaaminiمهسا_امینی #iranprotests #iranprotests2022 #iranprotest #newsworthywithab
Image Text: [NEWSWORTHY] Iran's morality police, 'disbanded' amid street protests Iran Disbands Morality Police, Considers Changing Hijab Laws, Official Says Iran Abolishes 'Morality Police' After Months- Long Protest Iran to disband morality police amid ongoing protests, says attorney general Iran Has Abolished Morality Police, an Official Suggests, After Months of Protests newsworthywithab A BIG WIN FOR PROTESTORS NOW: Iran has reportedly scrapped its morality police! Their main role was enforce strict rules how people, bumy women, dress and behave in public "Morality police have nothing to do with the judiciary

Description:
I think this came from @_the.wellness.therapist originally. Do read the caption 🙏🏼 #mahsaamini #womanlifefreedom #opiran 
👇 
Our sisters & brothers in Iran have lost access to the internet. They are risking their lives by simply refusing to wear the hijab & to peacefully protest. The regime of the Islamic Republic of Iran has shut down their connection to the outside world. They are being killed in the dark. I humbly ask for your support in sharing their stories & how they are courageously risking life & limb just to be heard. 

Iranians are asking for those outside of Iran to their voice.

1. Repost footage of protests to all social media platforms 

The Islamic Republic of Iran regime is blocking the internet. Iranians have to use VPN & other dangerous methods to get content out. When we reshare the videos/photos that do get out, we are helping to amplify the voices of Iranians. They want us to help get their stories out. 

Doing so also scares the regime because they don’t want the international community to see what is happening. Footage being widespread online also raises morale of Iranians to keep protesting. 

2. Use specific & creative hashtAgs to get thE word out 

Use these tags when you post: 
#mahsaamini #jinaamini #zhinaamini #Mahsa_Amini #iran #iranprotests

The tags above are designed for those who are already aware of whats happening in Iran. To get the story out to those who aren’t aware of it, use other popular hashtags such as: 

#food #fall #halloween #family #love #photography #news #politics etc. get creative! 

3. No war. No western intervention.
Keep your support focused on Iranian people fighting for their own liberation. Say No war on Iran. Iranians don’t want Western foreign intervention. They want to fight for their own liberation. They just want support from the international community. They want the atrocities documented. 

4. Organize to support iranians where you live 
Go out in the streets & make some noise. Attend support rallies in your country. DISCLAIMER: Due to sanctions against Iran, it is illegal to fundraise to send money there legally. If you see people collecting funds, be weary

Description:
As the Iranian Government continues to censor and isolate the people of Iran, it’s important to keep sharing the word out and join in community with those fighting for their bodily autonomy, a better life, and a free society. 
 
The @nytimes reports that outlets like Instagram, Twitter and Clubhouse “constitute the only means of holding the powers that be to account.” All of us sharing and reposting on social media has been “critical for a lot of people to wake up and see what's really going on,” said Shahin Milani, Executive Director for the U.S.-based Iran Human Rights Documentation Center (@iran.hrdc) “and that's really critical because no other outlet provides that." 
 
Join in this global community and uplift the fight by sharing this, reposting, and commenting for Mahsa Imani, the young woman who’s death in morality police detainment started these protests, and people all across Iran fighting for a better life, a just government and a free society. 

 
Keep sharing, keep re-tweeting, keep commenting, sign the petition, our voices can be a lifeline. More info at the link in our bio or at https://policy.futureswithoutviolence.org/resource_center/the-facts-about-iran/.
 
#MahsaAmini #JusticeForMahsaAmini #مهسا_امینی
